<s>matters of fact may be overturned, according as science 
and knowledge are enlarged, & new matters of fact are brought 
to light. for this reason a system of philosophy receives no 
sufficient sanction from its antiquity or long currency.” 
Therefore it is hoped it will not be deemed presumptuous to 
dissent from the opinions of even a Newton, when those 
opinions are unsupported by reason & experiment. 
Objections to the Newtonian Hypothesis.
I. By one part of the Theory the transmission or reflection of 
the rays is made to depend on certain original fits; by 
another part it depends on the thickness or thinness of the 
plate of Air; yet admitting both these conditions, we 
find that if the plate of Air is thin enough, all sorts of Rays 
pass through both surfaces, whether in fits of transmission 
or reflection.
II. Supposing the rays of light & the plate of Air to have 
the properties attributed to them, the case will admit of 
four varieties. 1st, A ray in a fit of transmission may 
fall on any of the transmitting thicknesses of the plates of 
Air, corresponding to the progression 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, &c. 2, 
A Ray in a fit of reflection may fall on any of the reflect-
ing thicknesses or intervals agreeing to the progression 1, 
3, 5, 7 9 &c. in the first case the ray must be transmitted, 
& in the second reflected, because that in both cases 
the supposed properties of the Rays, concur with the thick=
ness of the plate of Air to produce those effects. 
But 3d. A Ray in a fit of transmission may fall on a 
reflecting thickness of the plate of Air; in which case it 
must either be transmitted or reflected; if transmitted the 
reflecting thickness is of no use; & if reflected the fits are 
of no avail. 4th A Ray in a fit of reflection may fall 
on a transmitting interval; here also as in the 3d case, 
the one or the other of the above properties must be 
ineffectual.
III. Supposing the separation of the rays by the above 
two properties to be effectual, it would be so with regard 
to their transmissible or reflexible qualities only, but not 
at all with respect to colour, since the fits are supposed 
common to all colours.
